channel.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">REREV Automotive Glossary RSS
channel.description: Automotive terms and definitions from REREV.

image.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">REREV Automotive Glossary

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">A-pillar definition and meaning
item.description: The A-pillar is the vertical support structure on either side of a vehicle's windshield. It plays a crucial role in vehicle safety and aerodynamics. In many cars, the A-pillars are located at the extreme front corners, supporting the roof and housing airbags in some models.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">A/C compressor definition and meaning
item.description: The A/C compressor is a vital component of your air conditioning system. It is responsible for circulating refrigerant throughout the system, and its job is to pressurize the refrigerant so that it can evaporate and cool the air in your car. without the compressor, your A/C system would not be able to function. It is powered by the engine, and it uses a belt or pulley to connect to the crankshaft.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">A/C drain hose definition and meaning
item.description: A/C drain hose is a rubber or plastic hose that helps to drain water from your car’s air conditioner. The hose is usually located near the bottom of the A/C unit, and it may be connected to a drain pipe. Over time, the hose can become clogged with dirt and debris, which can cause it to leak or even break. If you notice water leaking from your car’s A/C unit, it’s important to check the drain hose for any blockages. You can clear the hose with a toothpick or other sharp object. If the hose is damaged, you’ll need to replace it.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">ACV definition and meaning
item.description: The actual cash value (ACV) of a car is its fair market value as determined by an appraiser. The ACV takes into account the vehicle’s age, condition, mileage, and any optional equipment or features that may add to its resale value. When an insurance company pays out a claim for a totaled car, the check is typically made out to the policyholder for the ACV of the vehicle..

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">AT-PZEV definition and meaning
item.description: AT-PZEV is an acronym for Advanced Technology Partial Zero Emission Vehicle. As its name suggests, AT-PZEV vehicles are designed to emit significantly fewer pollutants than traditional gasoline-powered cars and trucks. One of the key ways AT-PZEV vehicles reduce emissions is by using a technology called catalytic reduction. Catalytic reduction involves using a catalyst to convert harmful pollutants into less harmful gases.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">ATTS definition and meaning
item.description: The Automatic Torque Transfer System (ATTS) is a technology that allows for the seamless transfer of torque between the front and rear axles of a vehicle. This system is designed to improve traction and stability, particularly in off-road or slippery conditions. The automatic torque transfer system can be found on a variety of vehicles, including many SUVs and trucks. When engaged, the system will automatically distribute power to the wheels that have the most traction. This can help prevent wheel slip and improve overall handling. In some cases, the automatic torque transfer system can also provide a more comfortable ride by reducing vibrations.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">AWD definition and meaning
item.description: All-wheel drive (AWD) is a vehicle drivetrain that allows all four wheels to simultaneously receive power from the engine. This can provide increased traction and stability, especially in slippery or off-road conditions. While AWD systems have been around for decades, they have become increasingly popular in recent years as more and more automakers offer them as an option on their vehicles. Not all AWD systems are created equal; some are better suited for certain types of driving than others

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Tire accelerator definition and meaning
item.description: A tire accelerator is a chemical that speeds up the vulcanization of rubber in tires. It’s used in tire compounds to shorten the curing time. Several different types are available, each with its own advantages and disadvantages. The most common accelerator in tire compounds is zinc oxide, which provides good scorch safety and low vulcanization temperature. Other choices include thiazoles, sulfenamides, thiurams and dithiocarbamates. Each offers some advantage over the others, but all must be used within strict limits to avoid problems such as too rapid vulcanization (scorch) or poor crosslink density.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Accelerator pedal linkage definition and meaning
item.description: Accelerator pedal linkage is the system that connects the accelerator pedal to the throttle body or carburetor. This system allows the driver to control the amount of air and fuel entering the engine and, therefore, how much power the engine produces. The accelerator pedal linkage can be made up of various parts, depending on the vehicle. But typically, it includes a pushrod, clevis, and return spring.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Acquisition fee definition and meaning
item.description: An acquisition fee is a one-time charge assessed by a financial institution when you purchase a vehicle. This fee is generally rolled into your loan, so you’ll pay interest on it over the life of the loan. The acquisition fee can vary depending on the lender If you’re financing your vehicle through a dealership, they may try adding an “acquisition fee” as part of the total loan amount. This is negotiable, so be sure to ask about it and have them remove it if possible.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Active suspension definition and meaning
item.description: Active suspension is an automotive suspension that actively uses electronic or hydraulic controls to dampen bumps and vibrations. It was first introduced in the 1980s and has become increasingly popular, especially in luxury vehicles. Active suspension can provide a smoother ride than traditional passive suspension. It can also improve handling by reducing body roll and keeping the tires in better contact with the road. However, active suspension is more complex and expensive than traditional suspension, so it is not typically found in mass-market cars.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Activator definition and meaning
item.description: Activator chemicals are typically sulfur-based compounds, which act as catalysts to promote vulcanization in car tires. Other types of activators, such as zinc oxide, can also be used. The amount of activator used in a rubber compound varies depending on the type of vulcanization process being used and the desired properties of the finished product.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Active pedestrian protection system definition and meaning
item.description: An active pedestrian protection system is a vehicle safety feature that uses sensors to detect pedestrians and cyclists in the vehicle’s path and then takes steps to avoid or mitigate a collision. These systems can be found on both cars and trucks and are designed to protect not only the occupants of the vehicle but also pedestrians and cyclists outside of it.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">AdBlue definition and meaning
item.description: AdBlue is a trademarked name for a urea-based solution used in selective catalytic reduction (SCR) to reduce NOx emissions from diesel engines. SCR is a means of converting nitrogen oxides (NOx), which are harmful pollutants, into harmless nitrogen and water vapor. Diesel engines are responsible for a large percentage of NOx emissions, so using AdBlue can significantly reduce these emissions. In the European Union, AdBlue is required by law for use in new diesel vehicles.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Adaptive cruise control definition and meaning
item.description: Adaptive cruise control is a feature found on newer vehicles. It uses sensors to monitor the distance between your car and the one in front of you and then automatically adjusts your speed to maintain a safe following distance. This can help relieve some of the stress of driving in stop-and-go traffic or on long road trips. f you’re considering purchasing a vehicle with adaptive cruise control, it’s important to understand how it works and its limitations. Some adaptive cruise control systems can also bring your car to a complete stop if necessary and then resume driving when the way is clear.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Adaptive headlights definition and meaning
item.description: Adaptive headlights are a type of automotive headlight that adjusts the beam pattern in response to the vehicle’s speed and steering angle. This allows for better illumination of the road ahead, particularly when cornering.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Adjustable pedals definition and meaning
item.description: Adjustable pedals allow you to adjust the distance between the accelerator and brake pedal and the height of each pedal. Most newer cars come equipped with adjustable pedals, but if your car doesn’t have them, there are a number of aftermarket options available. There are many benefits to having adjustable pedals in your car. For one, they can help you customize your driving experience to suit your needs and preferences better. Additionally, they can provide more comfort and support while you’re behind the wheel, and can even help improve your fuel economy.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Adjustable suspension definition and meaning
item.description: Adjustable suspension is a type of vehicle suspension that allows the driver to adjust the ride height and firmness of the suspension. This can be done by adjusting the spring rate, damping, and/or ride height. The adjustable suspension provides passengers a more comfortable ride and improved driver handling. It also allows vehicles to be lowered or raised to clear obstacles or improve aerodynamics.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Aerodynamic drag definition and meaning
item.description: Aerodynamic drag is a force that acts on a car when it moves through the air. This force opposes the forward motion of the car and reduces its speed. The faster the car moves, the greater the aerodynamic drag.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Aftermarket accessory definition and meaning
item.description: An aftermarket accessory is optional extra equipment that can be added to a car. These can include things like alloy wheels, body kits, and spoilers. They are usually fitted by specialist companies or garages and can often improve the look of a car. Some aftermarket accessories can also improve a car’s performance, although this often depends on engine size and tuning factors. Aftermarket accessories can be expensive, so it’s essential to research them before you buy. You should also ensure that they are compatible with your car and are fitted correctly.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Tire age definition and meaning
item.description: As tires age, they can become more brittle and dry out. This can lead to cracks forming in the sidewalls or treads. Over time, these cracks can get larger and cause the tire to leak air or even blowout while in use. In extreme cases, older tires can cause accidents or injuries. If you have any concerns about the condition of your tires, it’s always best to have them checked by a professional.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Air conditioner refrigerant definition and meaning
item.description: An air conditioner refrigerant is a substance used in AC units to help cool the air. The refrigerant evaporates at a low temperature and condenses at a high temperature, drawing heat out of the air as it does so. This process helps to keep your home or office cool and comfortable.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Air conditioning filter definition and meaning
item.description: An air conditioning filter is a filter that is placed in the air conditioner unit of a car. This filter helps remove impurities from the air circulated through the car’s air conditioner. Doing so helps improve the air quality inside the vehicle and makes it more comfortable for the occupants.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Air dam definition and meaning
item.description: An air dam is a car part that helps improve a vehicle’s aerodynamics by redirecting airflow. It is located at the front of the car, below the bumper, and helps to reduce drag and improve fuel efficiency. Many newer cars have air dams as standard equipment, but they can also be added to older vehicles. Air dams can be made from different materials, such as plastic or fiberglass, and are typically painted to match the car’s body color. Some air dams can be removed for cleaning or repair, while others are permanently attached to the car.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Air filter restriction indicator definition and meaning
item.description: An air filter restriction indicator is a device that measures the amount of airflow restrictions in an air filter. It is used to help determine when the air filter needs to be replaced. The indicator typically consists of a small, hand-held sensor that is placed inside the air filter housing. The sensor measures the pressure drop across the air filter and displays the results on a digital readout.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Air pollution score definition and meaning
item.description: The air pollution score is a measure of the number of pollutants emitted by the car. The higher the score, the cleaner the car. The score is based on emissions tests conducted by the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). The air pollution score is a measure of the number of pollutants emitted by the car. The higher the score, the cleaner the car. The score is based on emissions tests conducted by the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Tire air pressure definition and meaning
item.description: Tire air pressure is the amount of air that is in each tire on your vehicle. The proper tire air pressure for your car is usually listed on a sticker inside the driver’s door. If not, you can usually find it in your car’s owner’s manual. Under-inflated tires can lead to poor handling and decreased fuel economy, while over-inflated tires can cause premature wear and tear. Check your tire pressure regularly to maintain proper inflation levels.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Air pump filter definition and meaning
item.description: An air pump filter is a device that helps remove impurities from the air being pumped into a car’s engine. The filter is usually located between the air pump and the carburetor or fuel injection system. It is important to keep the air pump filter clean so that it can continue to do its job properly. Otherwise, the engine may run poorly or stall completely.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Airbag definition and meaning
item.description: An airbag is a type of safety device that is installed in vehicles. It is designed to inflate in the event of a collision, providing a cushion for the vehicle’s occupants. Airbags have been shown to be effective in reducing injuries and fatalities in collisions. When a collision occurs, the airbag is deployed by a pyrotechnic device. The rapid inflation of the airbag cushions the occupants of the vehicle, dissipating the force of the impact. Airbags typically deploy within milliseconds of a collision.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Alignment definition and meaning
item.description: A tire alignment is a service performed by a mechanic to ensure that your vehicle’s tires are properly aligned. This helps to improve gas mileage, handling, and tire wear. There are three different types of tire alignments: caster, camber, and toe. Each type of alignment addresses different aspects of the tire’s position.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">All-season tires definition and meaning
item.description: All-season tires are designed to provide good traction and handling in various driving conditions, including wet and dry pavement and in light snow. They typically have deeper treads than summer tires and may also contain special compounds and tread patterns that help improve grip on slippery surfaces. Some all-season tires are even rated for severe snow service, which means they can be used year-round in areas where winter weather is a regular occurrence.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Alternator definition and meaning
item.description: An alternator is a device that produces alternating current (AC). It is commonly used in cars to power the electrical system when the engine is running. The alternator charges the battery and powers the car’s electrical accessories such as the lights, radio, and air conditioning. When the engine is not running, the battery supplies power to the car’s electrical accessories.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Antenna definition and meaning
item.description: The antenna is a device that helps to transmit and receive radio waves. In cars, the antenna is usually located on the roof or in the front grille. It is used to receive signals from radio towers and to send signals to other vehicles. The type of antenna used in a car depends on the car’s intended purpose. For example, a car that is designed for off-road use will likely have a different type of antenna than a car that is designed for city driving. Each type of antenna has its own advantages and disadvantages, so it’s important to choose the right one for your needs.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Anti-roll bar definition and meaning
item.description: An anti-roll bar is a device that helps resist a vehicle’s rolling. It is usually located between the wheels and consists of a bar connected to the suspension on each side. The purpose of an anti-roll bar is to keep the body of the vehicle level when cornering by providing resistance to the rolling force exerted by the vehicle’s weight. This resistance increases the tires’ grip on the road and helps prevent the car from skidding or sliding.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Anti-dive definition and meaning
item.description: Most modern cars are equipped with anti-dive suspension systems. This type of suspension is designed to prevent the nose of the car from “diving” down during braking. Anti-dive suspension systems use a variety of different methods to achieve this, but they all work to keep the car’s center of gravity more level during braking. This helps to improve braking performance and prevents the car from becoming unstable at high speeds.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Anti-locking brake system definition and meaning
item.description: The anti-locking brake system (ABS) is a safety feature that helps prevent the wheels from locking up during sudden braking or skidding. This prevents the vehicle from losing control and allows the driver to maintain control. ABS is an important safety feature that can help avoid accidents, but it is crucial to understand how it works and when to use it. Here’s a look at what ABS is and how it works.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Anti-theft alarm definition and meaning
item.description: An anti-theft alarm in cars is a device that helps to prevent your car from being stolen. It works by making a loud noise when someone tries to break into your car, which will hopefully deter the thief and make them go away. There are many different types of anti-theft alarms available on the market, so it is vital to do some research to find the one that best suits your needs. Some factors you may want to consider include the price, the features offered, and how easy it is to install. You should also ensure the alarm is compatible with your car model.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Anti-theft codes definition and meaning
item.description: Anti-theft codes are designed to prevent your car from being stolen. These codes are special sequences of numbers or letters that are required in order to start a car. They are typically stored in the engine control unit (ECU) and can only be accessed by authorized personnel. In the event that a car is stolen, the owner can contact the manufacturer and provide the code, which will disable the vehicle and make it unusable. Most anti-theft codes are four-digit codes that you can set yourself. Many newer cars also have transponder keys, which are more difficult to copy and therefore provide additional security. You should consider adding one if your car does not have an anti-theft code. Doing so could help to deter would-be thieves and protect your investment.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Anti-theft immobilizer definition and meaning
item.description: An anti-theft immobilizer is a device installed in a car to prevent it from being stolen. This system prevents the vehicle from being started without the proper key. Most modern cars have some form of anti-theft immobilizer fitted as standard. This can be in the form of a transponder system, where the key has a chip that sends a signal to the engine control unit (ECU), or it can be an electronic key fob with a built-in sensor that prevents the car from starting if it is not within range.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Antifreeze definition and meaning
item.description: Antifreeze is a substance used in vehicles and other machinery to keep them from freezing up in cold weather. It is typically made from ethylene glycol or propylene glycol and added to the water in the radiator to lower its freezing point. Antifreeze also raises the boiling point of the coolant, which helps to prevent engine overheating. In addition, it can help to protect against corrosion and scale buildup.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Tire antioxidants definition and meaning
item.description: Tire antioxidants help preserve the rubber in your tires, keeping them looking new and improving their lifespan. Over time, exposure to oxygen and other elements can cause tire rubber to degrade, resulting in cracks, splits, and eventually failure. Antioxidants work by forming a barrier between the rubber and the air, slowing the oxidation process and protecting your tires.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Tire aspect ratio definition and meaning
item.description: A tire’s aspect ratio is the ratio of its width to its height. In other words, it is the relationship between the tire’s width and the sidewall’s height. The aspect ratio is important because it affects several things, including the tire’s handling, ride comfort, and load-carrying capacity. A lower aspect ratio (i.e., a shorter sidewall) results in a stiffer ride and better handling but may sacrifice some ride comfort. A higher aspect ratio (i.e., a taller sidewall) results in a softer ride and more comfort but may not provide as much support for the vehicle’s weight.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Shift lock/starter safety switch definition and meaning
item.description: Auto shift lock/starter safety switch is a device that is installed in the shifter assembly of a vehicle. It is designed to prevent the engine from starting unless the shifter is in the proper position. This safety feature is important because it can help to prevent accidental or unauthorized starting of the vehicle. The switch also helps to ensure that the engine is not started while the vehicle is in gear, which could cause damage to the transmission.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Automated manual transmission definition and meaning
item.description: Automated manual transmission, also known as AMT, is a type of gearbox that combines features of both automatic and manual transmissions. AMT gearboxes are increasingly becoming popular in cars, especially in India where they offer a more affordable alternative to traditional automatic transmissions.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Automatic transmission definition and meaning
item.description: Automatic transmission is a type of gearbox that uses a computer to control the gear selection. The main benefit of an automatic transmission is that it takes the guesswork out of shifting gears, which can be helpful when driving in stop-and-go traffic or in other challenging situations. There are several different types of automatic transmissions, each with its own advantages and disadvantages.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Awareness aids definition and meaning
item.description: Awareness aids in cars are designed to help drivers be more aware of their surroundings. These aids can include features like blind spot monitoring, rear-view

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Axle definition and meaning
item.description: An axle is a shaft that connects two wheels. In a vehicle such as a car, the axle allows the wheels to rotate freely while supporting the car's weight. The

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">B-pillar definition and meaning
item.description: A B-pillar is the support structure between the side windows of a vehicle. The B-pillar typically contains the door latch and is often reinforced with

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">BMW definition and meaning
item.description: BMW stands for Bayerische Motoren Werke AG, which translates to Bavarian Motor Works. This German company started out as an aircraft engine manufacturer in

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Balance shaft definition and meaning
item.description: A balance shaft is a shaft that helps to cancel out the vibrations caused by the engine's pistons. It is usually located between the cylinder banks in the

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Ball joint definition and meaning
item.description: A ball joint is a mechanical part that connects two moving parts of a vehicle. It allows free movement in certain directions while still providing support and

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Bead definition and meaning
item.description: Bead of the wheel or tire bead is a phrase used to describe the outermost edge of a wheel. This area is often raised and reinforced to provide additional

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Beam axle definition and meaning
item.description: A beam axle is a type of automobile suspension system that uses a single beam or shaft to connect the left and right wheels. This construction is typical of

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">What is a blind spot? definition and meaning
item.description: A blind spot is an area around the vehicle that cannot be seen by the driver, either through the windshield or in the mirrors. Blind spots can be dangerous

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Bolstering definition and meaning
item.description: Bolstering is a term used to describe a car's structure's support to the occupants. It includes the seats, seatbelts, and airbags. The purpose of bolstering

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Boost pressure definition and meaning
item.description: Boost pressure is the extra pressure generated by a turbocharger or supercharger in an engine. More air is being forced into the engine, leading to increased

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Brake bias definition and meaning
item.description: Brake bias is the distribution of braking force between a vehicle's front and rear wheels. It is typically expressed as a percentage, with higher numbers

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Brake booster definition and meaning
item.description: A brake booster is a device that helps to increase the pressure in a vehicle's braking system. It is usually located between the master cylinder and the

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Brake fluid definition and meaning
item.description: Brake fluid is a hydraulic fluid used in brake systems. It transfers force from the pedal to the brakes, and also provides a way for the heat generated by

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Brake lining definition and meaning
item.description: Brake lining is a type of material used in brakes that helps to create friction and stopping power. It is typically made from a variety of materials such as

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Brake pedal definition and meaning
item.description: A brake pedal is a pedal in a vehicle that is pushed down in order to engage the brakes. The purpose of the brake pedal is to stop the vehicle from moving

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Braking assist definition and meaning
item.description: When you press the brake pedal, your car's braking assist system kicks in to help stop the vehicle. This system uses sensors to detect how hard you are

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Brush guard definition and meaning
item.description: A brush guard is a type of car accessory that helps protect the front of your vehicle from scratches, dents, and other damage. It typically consists of a

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Bumper definition and meaning
item.description: A bumper is a horizontal bar located at the front or rear of a vehicle. Its purpose is to absorb impact in a collision, minimizing damage to the vehicle's

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Bushing definition and meaning
item.description: Bushing is a term used to describe a type of connection between two parts of a car. It is typically a cylindrical piece of metal or plastic that fits over a

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">C-pillar definition and meaning
item.description: The C-pillar is the structural support between the rear door and the back window of a vehicle. In a unibody construction, it is typically made from sheet

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">CUV definition and meaning
item.description: A Crossover Utility Vehicle (CUV) is a vehicle built on a unibody construction, which combines features of a passenger car and an SUV. CUVs typically have

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">CV joint noise when driving straight — cause and fixes
